docs.title: Mojito libraries API references
docs.description: This section is intended as an API reference for each of the Mojito components:

frontMatter.title: Mojito libraries API references

next.title: Mojito test activation conditions & order of execution

docs.title: How to use hash functions for split test assignment
docs.description: Hash-based user assignment brings experimenters many benefits in running split tests. It's used extensively in the industry (section 4.1.2, page 6), at companies like LinkedIn, Google, Microsoft and many others. Compared to the ephemeral random numbers generated from PRNGs, hash-based decisioning gives you far greater control:

frontMatter.title: How to use hash functions for split test assignment

previous.title: Containing ramp spillover with partitioned ramps & hash based splits

docs.title: Example experiments, reports & recipes to get started
docs.description: Mojito makes it easy to build sophisticated experiments and insightful reports. While our API documentation may be fairly complete, examples are a useful way to tie it all together.

frontMatter.title: Example experiments, reports & recipes to get started

next.title: Build a simple A/B test in Mojito

docs.title: Run an AA test in Mojito
docs.description: An AA test runs identical variants against each other so experimenters may detect issues with sample ratio mismatch (SRM), other non-random differences between the groups or general instrumention issues.

frontMatter.title: Run an AA test in Mojito

previous.title: Build a simple A/B test in Mojito

next.title: Create & access your staging environment for A/B test QA with Requestly

docs.title: Triggering experiments remotely from other A/B tests or code
docs.description: There may come a time where you need to trigger an experiment remotely. Mojito lets you trigger experiments from outside the test object.

frontMatter.title: Triggering experiments remotely from other A/B tests or code

previous.title: Divert all traffic to the winning variant in Mojito

next.title: Containing ramp spillover with partitioned ramps & hash based splits

docs.title: Divert all traffic to the winning variant in Mojito
docs.description: When an experiment you run is wildly successful, you may want to send 100% of eligible traffic to the variant after completion. Usually we recommend hard-coding successful recipes, but when developer resources are scarce and the feature is delivering lots of value, you can use Mojito to divert traffic to the winner temporarily.
docs.sidebar_label: Divert traffic to a winning variant

frontMatter.title: Divert all traffic to the winning variant in Mojito
frontMatter.sidebar_label: Divert traffic to a winning variant

previous.title: Create & access your staging environment for A/B test QA with Requestly

next.title: Triggering experiments remotely from other A/B tests or code

docs.title: Containing ramp spillover with partitioned ramps & hash based splits
docs.description: Ramping-up experiments (from limited canary releases) is a popular way of managing risks and bugs in experiments before exposing all your traffic. A typical ramp-up process looks like this:

frontMatter.title: Containing ramp spillover with partitioned ramps & hash based splits

previous.title: Triggering experiments remotely from other A/B tests or code

next.title: How to use hash functions for split test assignment

docs.title: Create & access your staging environment for A/B test QA with Requestly
docs.description: Building experiments requires publishing experimental code to your website. In order to protect your mission-critical apps, it's recommended you publish and test code in a STAGING environment before you publish it into PRODUCTION. Doing so lets you catch heinous bugs before your users may encounter them.

frontMatter.title: Create & access your staging environment for A/B test QA with Requestly

docs.title: Mojito framework overview
docs.description: Mojito is a modular, source-controlled split testing framework that lets you build, launch and analyse experiments via Git/CI.

docs.title: Customise your decision adapter & bucketing
docs.description: Mojito gives users control over the decision/bucketing engine that assigns subjects to tests and recipes. This is especially useful in an ITP 2.3 world devoid of lasting client-set cookies.

docs.title: Customise your Mojito container shared code & tracking
docs.description: Shared JS defined in repo/lib/shared-code.js can be accessed by any experiment in the container. It's also used to define Mojito's optional parameters, e.g. Custom storage adaptors, Debug mode and Exclusion rules.

docs.title: Introduction to Mojito JS Delivery
docs.description: The Mojito JS Delivery component is a lightweight (<5.5kb) JS framework for building, publishing and tracking experiments on the web. Commonly known as A/B split testing, experimentation is a core pillar of Conversion Rate Optimisation.

frontMatter.title: Introduction to Mojito JS Delivery

previous.title: Mojito framework overview

next.title: Setting up experiments with Mojito JS Delivery

next.title: Hosting your Mojito split testing container

docs.title: Experiment shared code & other test parameters
docs.description: Your JS and CSS can have a shared scope within an experiment. E.g. two treatment variants might have some styling commonalities. We can reduce repeated code by sharing common elements across variants.

docs.title: Test object parameter reference in Mojito JS Delivery
docs.description: The test object contains everything an experiment needs to run, including the trigger, tracking information and recipe code (or variants). When you pass all this information into the Mojito.addTest() function, Mojito will execute all the logic in your experiment based on its order of execution.

frontMatter.title: Test object parameter reference in Mojito JS Delivery

previous.title: Mojito test activation conditions & order of execution

next.title: Storage adapter & tracking reference

docs.title: Upgrade your Mojito split testing container to the latest version
docs.description: An open-source split testing tool has real benefits - like being able to choose which updates to install, when. No third-parties will be making unwanted modifications to your site's JS.

frontMatter.title: Upgrade your Mojito split testing container to the latest version

previous.title: 5. Install your Mojito JS snippet

docs.title: Utility functions in Mojito JS Delivery
docs.description: We've baked a series of utility functions into Mojito which we think are handy for a wide range of experiments. We often encounter race conditions or are waiting for an element to exist before we can do something on the page. These utilities will allow you to overcome the majority of these issues.

frontMatter.title: Utility functions in Mojito JS Delivery

previous.title: Customise your decision adapter & bucketing

next.title: Gulp CLI reference for Mojito JS Delivery

docs.title: Mojito R Analytics Overview
docs.description: This component allows you to create fully-templateable experiment reports for Mojito Snowplow/Redshift, using R Markdown and HTML.

frontMatter.title: Mojito R Analytics Overview

docs.title: Mojito Snowplow/Redshift data models
docs.description: For measuring causality, we only count conversions taking place after a user is bucketed into a test. Tracking events before exposure to a variant only confounds the results.

frontMatter.title: Mojito Snowplow/Redshift data models

metadata.title: Release: Mojito JS Delivery v2.3.0
metadata.description: The focus of this release was a series of optimisations that allowed us to cut minified container weights by a huge 0.29KB for Mojito JS Delivery. Despite the large savings, we've retained the same behaviour in the library as before.

metadata.title: New site for Mojito documentation
metadata.description: We've now created a new dedicated resource for Mojito documentation and guides. This site should help new and existing Mojito users with making the most out of Mojito.
